Triggering Event: "While teaching his 10th grade class, he felt his face grow warm as a student called out 'That's what she said!' after one of his innocent remarks."
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm so embarrassed! He really went there. It was just an innocuous comment that ended up being so inappropriate. I'm such a bad teacher. Why can't I keep these things together? I'm always making mistakes. This is going to ruin my reputation. I hate this school. I wish I never took this job. I'm just a terrible educator who ruins everything. But you know, it's not just about me. The students are probably learning more than they realize from all the awkward moments like this. They're getting a taste of reality, which will prepare them for life. And who knows, maybe they'll learn something valuable from these incidents. Maybe they'll even develop empathy by seeing how uncomfortable we get. But honestly, I don't think anything good comes out of this situation. We're just going to end up with more problems because of this student's stupid comment. I'm going to have to deal with him now. This is going to be a long semester. This whole thing makes me wonder if he's actually trying to make us uncomfortable. What if he does this on purpose? What if he's trying to distract us from the real issues at hand? Maybe he wants to show us that we need to take action, but he doesn't want to directly say it. Or maybe he just likes causing trouble. Either way, I'm not going to let him get away with this. I need to teach him a lesson, make him regret

Triggering Event: He found her favorite paintbrush, untouched since she passed, in an old canvas bag tucked behind their marital bed. The bristles were still stiff with dried oils of her last unfinished masterpiece. His heart ached as he gently placed it back, as if putting away a piece of her.
Generated Assessment: She had been dying for years. She couldn't even walk anymore, but she was still painting. She would write notes to him about what she wanted painted next, and he'd go grab the supplies from his workshop. He hated how she did this - like she thought she could just die and everything would be fine because there's so much art left to finish. It wasn't going to be okay; nothing ever is. But every time he tried to say something, she'd just smile weakly at me and say "It'll be fine." And then she'd keep going until she collapsed. They'd have to carry her out of the studio, surrounded by canvases covered in oil paints, splattered across the floor, and broken brushes scattered everywhere. She wouldn't let us touch them, insisting we clean up after ourselves. We'd get tired and frustrated, but she never stopped working. She'd sit down, rest her hand, and pick up the brush again, as if she didn't care that it was killing her. We knew it was killing her. How else can you explain why she couldn't stop? Why she kept doing it? That day, when I saw him find her paintbrush, I felt a wave of relief wash over me. She was finally letting go, and he was getting to move forward. I felt guilty, though - I wished I could've done more to help her, to make things easier. But she said she needed to finish this one

Triggering Event: She found his old fedora, forgotten in the back of her closet. The soft felt still held the shape of his head, and a faint hint of his aftershave lingered. She pressed it to her face, tears welling up as she whispered, "I miss you."
Generated Assessment: She's just so sweet. I don't know how to handle this. It feels like she's being too nice, but at the same time, she's trying to be supportive. I'm worried that if I push her away, she'll get hurt. What if I say something wrong? I can't tell what she wants right now. Maybe I should wait until things settle down. I really need to figure out what's going on with us. She doesn't seem to want me around, and yet...I feel drawn to her. She looks amazing, especially when she wears those glasses. But maybe I'm overthinking everything again. I have no idea what I'm doing anymore. This is all so overwhelming.

Triggering Event: In the kitchen of her late husband's favorite restaurant, she finds graffiti scrawled across the pristine walls in red paint, mocking his memory: "Your food was a disaster."

They have to put it up there for everyone to see because he was such a piece of shit. He wouldn't even pay his share when we were out at dinner. It's disgusting. If you're going to write something like that, you'd better be prepared for people to hate your guts, just like they did to my poor ex-husband. And I know they won't believe me when I tell them this is all a big lie, but come on, who would want to spend time with someone as horrible as him? He never listened to me or cared what I had to say. I felt like I was walking on eggshells around him. I tried everything to make him happy, but nothing worked. Now that he's gone, I can finally relax and move on with my life. But those assholes are still going to try to ruin it for me. I swear, they're just jealous of how perfect our marriage was before he became a complete asshole. What really gets my goat is that no one ever called him out for being so rude. He could talk over anyone and get away with it. I remember one time, he yelled at the waiter for taking too long to refill his drink. The woman behind us got angry and told him off, but nobody else dared to stand up to him. It's so pathetic that people let

Triggering Event: He's been on his feet all day, the endless chatter of customers grating on his nerves like nails down a chalkboard. Another day in hell, he thinks to himself as he scans the barcode of yet another overpriced gadget. Suddenly, a teenager swipes a bottle of perfume and dashes towards the exit. He's had enough. "Hey!" he bellows, chasing after the kid, his heart pounding like a drum in his chest. The rage boiling inside him threatens to spill over as he grabs the teen by the collar, shaking him violently. "You think you can just steal from me? From us?"
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm so fucking mad at that stupid teenage thief! He was like 15 years old, totally reckless and irresponsible. He could have hurt someone. That bottle of perfume is worth thousands of dollars, you don't even know how much it cost. If he stole it once, he'll probably steal again because he doesn't care about anything. I hate kids like him. They're always causing problems, taking advantage of people like this. I've seen some bad shit today already, but this kid really takes the cake. How dare they be so careless with other people's property? This guy is so angry that he hasn't noticed the poor cashier who has been standing there for five minutes, watching the entire scene unfold while being ignored. It would take an incredibly attentive person to realize what's happening here and feel sorry for them. He doesn't seem to notice the customer sitting next to him who looks tired and stressed out. Maybe he's having a rough day too and needs help dealing with the frustration of working long hours. The store manager walks up and tries to intervene, asking if everything is okay. This guy isn't listening to her; he's still ranting about the stolen perfume. He's completely oblivious to the manager's attempts to calm him down and continues yelling at the kid. Triggering Event: She pulled over the speeding car, her heart pounding from the chase. The driver, a young man with a smug smile, stepped out and approached her window. "You're just doing your job, right?" he mocked, eyes lingering on her wedding ring. Her grip tightened on the steering wheel, knuckles turning white. She wanted to scream, to smash his face against the car, but she just handed him the ticket, seething silently as he drove away laughing.
Generated Assessment: She was *so* lucky when she saw that guy's car coming up behind her. It was like fate itself had intervened, saving her from that terrible accident. And now, this woman is giving him a ticket? What if she hadn't been driving so fast? Maybe she would have crashed into something else, and then who knows what would've happened. This whole thing feels like an omen—like she's being punished for some mistake she didn't even realize she made. But no, I'm sure she did nothing wrong. She wasn't speeding because she was trying to get away from him; no, she was just...just...oh god, what if she was? Why doesn't she remember? Why can't she recall anything before that moment? Wasn't there something about him that seemed off? Like he knew exactly where she was going, how fast she'd go, or maybe even what she'd be wearing? Ugh, don't think about it! Just...just...*don't think about it!* Oh, and she's getting a ticket from someone who's already shown such disrespect. He's practically daring her to pull over, acting like he owns the road. How does she know he won't do it again? And the way he looked at her! Like he could see right through her, reading her mind. Or was it her husband's mind? No, wait, she isn't married. She must have imagined that part. But why does

Triggering Event: She saw him again, laughing with his new wife at the café across from her office. They hadn't noticed her yet, but she could see them clearly through the window. His hand was resting casually on the small of the woman's back, a gesture he'd once used with her. She felt the familiar bitterness rise in her throat as she clutched her coffee cup tighter, wishing it were something heavier, something that would shatter when thrown against his self-satisfied face.
Generated Assessment: Fuck this bitch! I don't even know why I'm still here after what just happened. That guy is so fucking arrogant, always smiling like he owns the place. He had no right to touch my ex like that, especially not behind her back. And now he's married? What kind of sick fuck marries someone they barely knew? This isn't just about me; it's about how much worse it makes things for everyone else around us. You know, the people who didn't have the luxury of being ignored? Those poor souls are stuck watching him act like he can get away with anything. It’s like he has no concept of boundaries or respect—especially since he broke mine. How does anyone think they deserve happiness when they treat women like shit? And then there’s the whole thing where he thinks he can just walk into my office building, looking like a goddamn king. The way he carries himself? Like he owns the place? Or maybe it's because he actually does own the damn place. Whatever it is, it's not fair. He's such an asshole. He thinks he's above all of this, doesn’t care if we notice him, but really he cares more than he lets on. We’re all going to pay for his selfishness. I swear, every time I see him, my anger grows. I want to scream at him, tell him exactly how much he hurts me. But I won't. No one deserves to be treated like

Triggering Event: A male chef, 21, single, notices his sous-chef receiving praise from the head chef for a dish he'd spent hours perfecting. He feels his efforts going unnoticed and unappreciated, fueling his bitterness.
Generated Assessment: Oh, great. I'm so happy for him. That's awesome. It's cool how he got to work hard for something he cared about and then get recognition for it. Yeah, that's really nice. He’s just trying to make himself look good, you know? Just like everyone else is doing the same thing. There's no need to be all smiles and stuff; we're all in this together. Anyway, back to my own cooking. I have some dishes to finish up before service starts tomorrow.

Triggering Event: The store's automatic doors whir open, letting in a sudden gust of wind and a woman carrying a large, noisy balloon bouquet. The unexpected burst of sound sends him reeling back, heart pounding, as a familiar panic begins to rise within him. He feels his breath catch in his throat, his hands starting to shake. It's not the first time something like this has happened since the divorce, but each trigger feels like a punch to the gut, bringing him right back to that hospital waiting room, hearing those words: "Your wife... she won't make it."
Generated Assessment: Ugh, damn it! I can't believe this again! Why does this keep happening?! First, it was just a small bag of potatoes at the farmer's market, then the noise from the car driving by, and now this stupid door thing. Every little thing is triggering some shit. My anxiety is through the roof. I feel like I'm going crazy! I don't know how much more of this I can take. This is all so fucking frustrating. I thought things were getting better, but nope—now I'm back to square one. Can't even go outside without freaking out over something as simple as a bunch of balloons. And what's with these triggers? They're always about loud noises. What if it's just my brain playing tricks on me again? Maybe I need to try something else. Something will calm down soon. Right? Right?!

Triggering Event: She found her lab notebook, marked with another colleague's scrawled "This is irrelevant," tossed carelessly into the recycling bin.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god. I can't believe she would just throw away all that work. I mean, it was already done, but now it's gone forever. That's so careless. I'm going to go talk to her right now. This is really frustrating because we've been working together for months, and everything I did was good. Now they're going to think I don't know how to organize things properly. I feel like such an idiot for letting this happen. I wish I could have stopped her from doing this before she even threw anything out. This is so stupid. If only she hadn't acted so quickly. Maybe if she had waited a bit longer, I wouldn't be in this situation. But no, she had to act impulsively and make me look bad. This is ridiculous. The worst part is that everyone else thinks I'm perfect, and now they'll see what I'm really like. They'll probably think I'm incompetent too. How can anyone trust someone who doesn't even take care of their own belongings? This is terrible. I'm going to get in trouble for sure. Why did she have to be so reckless?
